ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I got a broad understanding of the evolution of popular music from the 60's to today.
I was able to explore albums and music genres that I hadn't yet explored. The class is incredibly flexible, which allows you to tailor the biweekly presentations/assignments to your interests.
Really helped me develop how to think about music, music theory, and popular music history.
How to analyze pop music in a theoretical way similar to classical music

Strengthened abilities of harmonic and melodic transcription and analysis, ear training, active listening, etc. Also learned about the history of pop music and various genre's (disco, hip hop, alt rock) position within history.
I learned a lot about genre signifiers and the development of genres from the 60s to the present in popular music. I learned to analyze songs and communicate my observations and analysis.

A continuation of MUSI 207 - we learned about different signifiers for genres throughout popular music history from the 60's through the present day as well as the cultural and social context of the music.  Rock, prog rock, punk, synth-pop, disco, rap, etc, you name it.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: I loved the seminar style of this class (as opposed to 207). I really got to learn from all the other students, and I liked all the discussions we had. The only improvement I could see is a little more theory teaching in class. Overall, the best fifth class I could take--no stress, learned a lot, and fun!

Strengths: The flexibility you have to study what you want is excitingyou're not bound to a music assignment that doesn't excite you, which I've heard is a problem with other classes in the music department. This class is also very little workit's effectively a twice-a-week music discussion hang.

Weaknesses: I didn't learn very much because you aren't expected to produce any serious theoretical analysis of popular music. The assignments could also be more creative and educational. It often felt like a compromise between a theory and history class, with not enough of either. The conversations are also usually disorganized.
I liked the loose and unstructured nature of our discussions. However, sometimes it felt like it could cause people to get left out when the discussion got too high-level and fast-paced.

Strengths: always very engaging and fun, professor always listened to what students wanted
Weaknesses: none

Strengths: Prof. Adam is one of the best profs at Yale, maybe my favorite I've had. His attitude, curiosity, encouragement of students' interests, enthusiasm for the material, and utter expertise make this class rock. He fosters a wonderful vibe (along with all the students) of mutual respect, excitement, and effort. I looked so forward to this class everyday. 

Weaknesses: None

Weeks of teacher-led material alternate with student presentations, so you get the opportunity to share your insights on your choice of music and hear the same from your classmates.  Incredibly engaging!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! If you care about music and want to discuss opinions on popular music, you'll enjoy this class! You get out of it whatever you put in.

Only if you're looking for a very light class that occasionally provides interesting music discussion. Or if you really want an excuse to dive into some new music and won't do it without the structure of a class. Otherwise, I'd pass.
Yes! Fun and informative discussions about music.
Absolutely! Even if you don't have a music theory background

1000%. Favorite class I've taken at Yale. It's just delightful, no other way about it. You'll learn so much form Prof. Adam and from the other students. All of the work is meaningful, ie no assignments feel like 'busy work.'
Yes! Nate is a fantastic teacher and the class is so unique and interesting and very educational about popular music theory, which is a field that is not widely covered or understood.
If you enjoyed 207 and would like to apply the basics you learned to analyze more music across different genres, then absolutely!  The class will be amazing.
